Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my stepmom just as I was about to join the team meeting. She and Dad expected me to check in every day, to share how things were going, and to reply quickly. It was our routine, a way to keep close even though I’d moved out. But today, the meeting was crucial—my manager had made it clear that everyone’s input was needed, and the updates wouldn’t be sent out afterward. I stared at the screen, torn. If I ignored the message, my parents would worry, maybe even feel hurt, thinking I was pulling away. But if I started typing now, I’d be distracted, maybe miss my chance to contribute, or worse, seem uncommitted to the team. My heart pounded as I hovered between the chat app and the meeting link, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention at the same time.
